conclusion: The basketball is dropped from a height H with initial velocity v_i = 0.
The gravitational potential energy at height H is mgh.
The air resistance force is lambda mg.
During the descent from height H to the ground, the work done by air resistance is lambda mgH.
The kinetic energy just before impact is mgH - lambda mgH = mgH(1 - lambda).
Using the kinetic energy formula, 1/2mv^2 = mgH(1 - lambda).
Solving for v_pre-collision gives v_pre-collision = sqrt(2gH(1 - lambda)).
Let the post-collision velocity be v_post-collision.
The basketball rebounds to a height h.
The kinetic energy just after impact is 1/2mv_post-collision^2 = mgh(1 - lambda).
Solving for v_post-collision gives v_post-collision = sqrt(2gh(1 - lambda)).
The ratio of post-collision velocity to pre-collision velocity is sqrt(2gh(1 - lambda))/sqrt(2gH(1 - lambda)).
Simplifying the ratio gives v_post-collision/v_pre-collision = sqrt(h/H).
The final answer is the ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity is sqrt(h/H).
